query: What is the catechol benchmark dataset evaluation methodology and how did they achieve MSE 0.0039 in the original paper?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: The provided search results do not contain information about the specific evaluation methodology used for the Catechol benchmark dataset or how the original paper achieved an MSE of 0.0039. ([arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1), [arxiv.org/abs/2512.19530](https://arxiv.org/abs/2512.19530))

results.title: The Catechol Benchmark: Time-series Solvent Selection ...
results.text:
The Catechol Benchmark: Time-series Solvent Selection Data for Few-shot Machine Learning
# The Catechol Benchmark: Time-series Solvent Selection Data for Few-shot Machine Learning
Toby Boyne1, Juan S. Campos1, Becky D. Langdon1, Jixiang Qing1, Yilin Xie1
Shiqiang Zhang1, Calvin Tsay1, Ruth Misener1, Daniel W. Davies2, Kim E. Jelfs2
Sarah Boyall3, Thomas M. Dixon3, Linden Schrecker3, Jose Pablo Folch3†
Department of Computing, Imperial College, London, UK1
Department of Chemistry, Imperial College, London, UK2
SOLVE Chemistry, London, UK3t.boyne23@imperial.ac.uk;†jose@solvechemistry.com
###### Abstract
Machine learning has promised to change the landscape of laboratory chemistry, with impressive results in molecular property prediction and reaction retro-synthesis. However, chemical datasets are often inaccessible to the machine learning community as they tend to require cleaning, thorough understanding of the chemistry, or are simply not available. In this paper, we introduce a novel dataset for yield prediction, providing the first-ever transient flow dataset for machine learning benchmarking, covering over 1200 process conditions. While previous datasets focus on discrete parameters, our experimental set-up allow us to sample a large number of continuous process conditions, generating new challenges for machine learning models. We focus on solvent selection, a task that is particularly difficult to model theoretically and therefore ripe for machine learning applications. We showcase benchmarking for regression algorithms, transfer-learning approaches, feature engineering, and active learning, with important applications towards solvent replacement and sustainable manufacturing.
## 1Introduction
Machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) have showcased enormous potential in empowering the world of the natural sciences: from famous examples such as AlphaFold for protein predictions> [
[> 1
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib1)> ]
, to fusion reactor control> [
[> 2
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib2)> ]
, disease detection> [
[> 3
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib3)> ]
, battery design> [
[> 4
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib4)> ]
, and material discovery> [
[> 5
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib5)> ]
, among many more. However, we seldom see the machine learning community benchmark new methods in physical science datasets, mostly due to the difficulty in cleaning real-world data, the need for interdisciplinary understanding to correctly benchmark, and most importantly, how expensive the data can be to produce, resulting in many datasets being locked behind closed doors by large companies.
AIchemy ([https://aichemy.ac.uk](https://aichemy.ac.uk)) is an interdisciplinary UK hub with the mission of transforming the chemistry-AI interface via aiding the collaboration of chemists and AI researchers, as well as addressing gaps in data standards, curation, and availability for AI use. In partnership with SOLVE Chemistry ([https://www.solvechemistry.com](https://www.solvechemistry.com)), we present a first important step into addressing the dataset gap with the introduction of a new and unique open dataset for benchmarking low-data machine learning algorithms for chemistry.
Solvent selection is one of the biggest challenges for chemical manufacturing, with solvents often being the main source of waste in the manufacturing process> [
[> 6
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib6)> ]
. Increased regulation on solvents and a drive to making process manufacturing more sustainable led to an interest in the discovery of greener solvents and for improved solvent replacement tools. However, most of the solvent replacement tools focus purely on learning unsupervised representations of solvents, with the hope that experimentalists can find solvents with similar properties to replace those with environmental concerns. A much stronger approach would consider the interaction of a variety of different solvents with a reaction of interest to directly predict reaction yields, in such a way that the best possible solvent can be selected according to a yield-sustainability trade-off.
Machine learning approaches have been shown to be a powerful tool for the prediction of chemical reaction conditions. Success has been reported in retro-synthesis> [
[> 7
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib7)> , [> 8
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib8)> ]
, condition recommendations> [
[> 9
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib9)> ]
, product predictions> [
[> 10
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib10)> , [> 11
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib11)> ]
, among others. While yield prediction has proven to be more difficult due to large inconsistencies in procedure and data reporting> [
[> 12
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib12)> ]
, we have still seen promising yield prediction results for smaller and more carefully curated datasets> [
[> 13
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib13)> , [> 14
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib14)> , [> 15
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib15)> , [> 16
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib16)> ]
. However, these datasets lack the continuous reaction conditions, such as temperature and residence time, that are required to scale-up processes to practical manufacturing conditions.
In this paper, we release the first machine-learning-ready transient flow dataset, a framework that allows for quick and efficient screening of continuous reaction conditions. We specifically provide yield data over the uni-molecular allyl substituted catechol reaction, shown in Figure[1](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#S1.F1), with dense measurements across the residence time, temperature, and solvent space. We further showcase how this type ofkinetic dataposes new challenges to current machine learning methods for chemistry, and identify how the challenges can potentially be tackled by the community.
![Refer to caption](extracted/6524982/figures/Project2_rxn.png)Figure 1:Data was gathered on the rearrangement of allyl substituted catechol. By subjecting the reaction mixture to high temperatures, we begin a cascade reaction forming multiple rearrangement products. We investigate the yield of the reaction for a range of different solvents. Product 1 was not observed and reacted immediately to form Product 2 and later 3.
### 1.1Related works
Reaction datasets are common in chemistry research, but their suitability for machine learning benchmarking tends to be poor. This can be a result of improper formatting or documentation, incomplete information about reaction conditions or the experimental set-up, or the lack of machine readability, leading to limited usage by the ML community. However, some effort has been made to address this, with the biggest example being the creation of the Open Reaction Database (ORD)> [
[> 17
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib17)> ]
, a repository containing over 2M different reactions, many of which come from US patent data (USPTO)> [
[> 18
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib18)> ]
. However, the dataset falls short in some aspects, in particular with respect to machine learning readiness and data inconsistencies across reactions.
ORDerly> [
[> 12
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib12)> ]
allows for easy cleaning and preparation of ORD data, showing the promise of the dataset for forward and retro-synthetic prediction using transformers; however, it also shows that yield prediction cannot be done well due to data inconsistencies.> Schwaller et al. [
[> 13
](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1#bib.bib13)> ]
drew similar conclusions when using the USPTO dataset, stating that reaction conditions such as temperature, concentrations, and duration have a significant effect on yield. The assumption that every reaction in the dataset is optimized for reaction param...

# Computer Science \> Machine Learning
**arXiv:2512.19530**(cs)
[Submitted on 22 Dec 2025]
# Title:Learning Continuous Solvent Effects from Transient Flow Data: A Graph Neural Network Benchmark on Catechol Rearrangement
Authors:[Hongsheng Xing](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Xing,+H),[Qiuxin Si](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Si,+Q)
View a PDF of the paper titled Learning Continuous Solvent Effects from Transient Flow Data: A Graph Neural Network Benchmark on Catechol Rearrangement, by Hongsheng Xing and Qiuxin Si
[View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2512.19530)[HTML (experimental)](https://arxiv.org/html/2512.19530v1)> > Abstract:
> Predicting reaction outcomes across continuous solvent composition ranges remains a critical challenge in organic synthesis and process chemistry. Traditional machine learning approaches often treat solvent identity as a discrete categorical variable, which prevents systematic interpolation and extrapolation across the solvent space. This work introduces the \textbf{Catechol Benchmark}, a high-throughput transient flow chemistry dataset comprising 1,227 experimental yield measurements for the rearrangement of allyl-substituted catechol in 24 pure solvents and their binary mixtures, parameterized by continuous volume fractions ($\% B$). We evaluate various architectures under rigorous leave-one-solvent-out and leave-one-mixture-out protocols to test generalization to unseen chemical environments.
> Our results demonstrate that classical tabular methods (e.g., Gradient-Boosted Decision Trees) and large language model embeddings (e.g., Qwen-7B) struggle with quantitative precision, yielding Mean Squared Errors (MSE) of 0.099 and 0.129, respectively. In contrast, we propose a hybrid GNN-based architecture that integrates Graph Attention Networks (GATs) with Differential Reaction Fingerprints (DRFP) and learned mixture-aware solvent encodings. This approach achieves an \textbf{MSE of 0.0039} ($\pm$ 0.0003), representing a 60\% error reduction over competitive baselines and a $>25\times$ improvement over tabular ensembles. Ablation studies confirm that explicit molecular graph message-passing and continuous mixture encoding are essential for robust generalization. The complete dataset, evaluation protocols, and reference implementations are released to facilitate data-efficient reaction prediction and continuous solvent representation learning. Comments:|13 pages, 6 figures|
Subjects:|Machine Learning (cs.LG); Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI)|
MSCclasses:|68T07, 92E20, 62M45|
ACMclasses:|I.2.1; I.2.6; J.2|

## Abstract
**Click to copy section linkSection link copied!
![](https://pubs.acs.org/cms/10.1021/acs.jpcb.4c08356/asset/images/medium/jp4c08356_0007.gif)
[High Resolution Image](https://pubs.acs.org/cms/10.1021/acs.jpcb.4c08356/asset/images/large/jp4c08356_0007.jpeg)
[Download MS PowerPoint Slide](https://pubs.acs.org/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.jpcb.4c08356&id=_i1)
Approximate complete basis set CCSD(T), MP2, and HF calculations are performed for thirty-two catechol-containing complexes. These complexes, which include metal-coordination, hydrogen-bonding, π-stacking, and other, weaker interactions, are representative of the types of noncovalent interactions that catechols undergo when binding to proteins in the body, such as in the biosynthesis of dopamine. The catechols studied include the neutral catechol and dinitrocatechol molecules, as well as the charged dopamine and DOPAC molecules. Calculations with twenty-one density functional theory methods with triple and quadruple-ζ basis sets are evaluated against the CCSD(T) benchmarks to ascertain their accuracy. It is found that MN15, M06-2X-D3, ωB97XD, ωB97M-V, and CAM-B3LYP-D3 provide good accuracy when compared with CCSD(T)/CBS calculations for these systems and may be used for the study of relevant biological systems. The local DPLNO CCSD(T) method is also evaluated against the CCSD(T)/CBS energies for a subset of the complexes and found to agree within 1–3%, with a maximum difference of 0.26 kcal/mol.
This publi...

results.title: The Catechol Benchmark: Time-series Solvent Selection Data for Few-shot Machine Learning
results.text:
Authors: [Toby Boyne](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Boyne,+T), [Juan S. Campos](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Campos,+J+S), [Becky D. Langdon](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Langdon,+B+D), [Jixiang Qing](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Qing,+J), [Yilin Xie](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Xie,+Y), [Shiqiang Zhang](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Zhang,+S), [Calvin Tsay](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Tsay,+C), [Ruth Misener](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Misener,+R), [Daniel W. Davies](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Davies,+D+W), [Kim E. Jelfs](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Jelfs,+K+E), [Sarah Boyall](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Boyall,+S), [Thomas M. Dixon](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Dixon,+T+M), [Linden Schrecker](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Schrecker,+L), [Jose Pablo Folch](https://arxiv.org/search/cs?searchtype=author&query=Folch,+J+P)

[View PDF](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2506.07619) [HTML (experimental)](https://arxiv.org/html/2506.07619v1)

> Abstract:Machine learning has promised to change the landscape of laboratory chemistry, with impressive results in molecular property prediction and reaction retro-synthesis. However, chemical datasets are often inaccessible to the machine learning community as they tend to require cleaning, thorough understanding of the chemistry, or are simply not available. In this paper, we introduce a novel dataset for yield prediction, providing the first-ever transient flow dataset for machine learning benchmarking, covering over 1200 process conditions. While previous datasets focus on discrete parameters, our experimental set-up allow us to sample a large number of continuous process conditions, generating new challenges for machine learning models. We focus on solvent selection, a task that is particularly difficult to model theoretically and therefore ripe for machine learning applications. We showcase benchmarking for regression algorithms, transfer-learning approaches, feature engineering, and active learning, with important applications towards solvent replacement and sustainable manufacturing.

15 1 Introduction
16 Machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) have showcased enormous potential in em17 powering the world of the natural sciences: from famous examples such as AlphaFold for protein
18 predictions [1], to fusion reactor control [2], disease detection [3], battery design [4], and material
19 discovery [5], among many more. However, we seldom see the machine learning community bench20 mark new methods in physical science datasets, mostly due to the difficulty in cleaning real-world
21 data, the need for interdisciplinary understanding to correctly benchmark, and most importantly, how
22 expensive the data can be to produce, resulting in many datasets being locked behind closed doors by
23 large companies.
24 AIchemy (https://aichemy.ac.uk) is an interdisciplinary UK hub with the mission of transform25 ing the chemistry-AI interface via aiding the collaboration of chemists and AI researchers, as well as
26 addressing gaps in data standards, curation, and availability for AI use. In partnership with SOLVE
27 Chemistry (https://www.solvechemistry.com), we present a first important step into addressing
28 the dataset gap with the introduction of a new and unique open dataset for benchmarking low-data
29 machine learning algorithms for chemistry.
30 Solvent selection is one of the biggest challenges for chemical manufacturing, with solvents often
31 being the main source of waste in the manufacturing process [6]. Increased regulation on solvents and
32 a drive to making process manufacturing more sustainable led to an interest in the discovery of greener

33 solvents and for improved solvent replacement tools. However, most of the solvent replacement tools
34 focus purely on learning unsupervised representations of solvents, with the hope that experimentalists
35 can find solvents with similar properties to replace those with environmental concerns. A much
36 stronger approach would consider the interaction of a variety of different solvents with a reaction of
37 interest to directly predict reaction yields, in such a way that the best possible solvent can be selected
38 according to a yield-sustainability trade-off.
39 Machine learning approaches have been shown to be a powerful tool for the prediction of chemical
40 reaction conditions. Success has been reported in retro-synthesis [7, 8], condition recommendations
41 [9], product predictions [10, 11], among others. While yield prediction has proven to be more difficult
42 due to large inconsistencies in procedure and data reporting [12], we have still seen promising yield
43 prediction results for smaller and more carefully curated datasets [13–16]. However, these datasets
44 lack the continuous reaction conditions, such as temperature and residence time, that are required to
45 scale-up processes to practical manufacturing conditions.
46 In this paper, we release the first machine-learning-ready transient flow dataset, a framework that
47 allows for quick and efficient screening of continuous reaction conditions. We specifically provide
48 yield data over the uni-molecular allyl substituted catechol reaction, shown in Figure 1, with dense
49 measurements across the residence time, temperature, and solvent space. We answer the call for
50 more flow chemistry reaction data [17], further showcase how this type of kinetic data poses new
51 challenges to current machine learning methods for chemistry, and identify potential solutions.
52 1.1 Related works
53 Reaction datasets are common in chemistry research, but their suitability for machine learning
54 benchmarking tends to be poor. This can be a result of improper formatting or documentation,
55 incomplete information about reaction conditions or the experimental set-up, or the lack of machine
56 readability, leading to limited usage by the ML community. However, some effort has been made
57 to address this, with the biggest example being the creation of the Open Reaction Database (ORD)
58 [18], a repository containing over 2M different reactions, many of which come from US patent data
59 (USPTO) [19]. However, the dataset falls short in some aspects, in particular with respect to machine
60 learning readiness and data inconsistencies across reactions.
61 ORDerly [12] allows for easy cleaning and preparation of ORD data, showing the promise of the
62 dataset for forward and retro-synthetic prediction using transformers; however, it also shows that
63 yield prediction cannot be done well due to data inconsistencies. Schwaller et al. [13] drew similar
64 conclusions when using the USPTO dataset, stating that reaction conditions such as temperature,
65 concentrations, and duration have a significant effect on yield. The assumption that every reaction in
66 the dataset is optimized for reaction parameters proved too loose, resulting in inaccurate predictive
67 models for yield, and highlighting the importance of creating datasets with full (including potentially
68 sub-optimal) reaction conditions.
69 More relevant to our work, Perera et al. [20] introduced a dataset of 5760 Suzuki-Miyaura cross70 coupling reactions, Ahneman et al. [21] introduced a dataset of 3956 Buchwald–Hartwig aminations,
71 and Prieto Kullmer et al. [22] investigated screening additives for Ni-catalysed reactions, all for the
72 purposes of yield prediction. The datasets have been used in the benchmarking of Gaussian processes
73 and Bayesian neural networks [14], deep learning models [13], language-model-based embeddings

74 [16], data augmentation techniques [23], and Bayesian optimisation [15]. In each case, the datasets
75 focus on discrete reaction variables, such as ligand, base, additives, or reactants at fixed temperatures
76 and residence times. We are instead introducing a dataset rich in continuous reaction conditions (in

Abstract
Machine learning has promised to change the landscape of laboratory chemistry, with impressive results in molecular property prediction and reaction retrosynthesis. However, chemical datasets are often inaccessible to the machine
learning community as they tend to require cleaning, thorough understanding of the
chemistry, or are simply not available. In this paper, we introduce a novel dataset
for yield prediction, providing the first-ever transient flow dataset for machine
learning benchmarking, covering over 1200 process conditions. While previous
datasets focus on discrete parameters, our experimental set-up allow us to sample
a large number of continuous process conditions, generating new challenges for
machine learning models. We focus on solvent selection, a task that is particularly
difficult to model theoretically and therefore ripe for machine learning applications. We showcase benchmarking for regression algorithms, transfer-learning
approaches, feature engineering, and active learning, with important applications
towards solvent replacement and sustainable manufacturing.
1 Introduction
Machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) have showcased enormous potential in empowering the world of the natural sciences: from famous examples such as AlphaFold for protein
predictions [1], to fusion reactor control [2], disease detection [3], battery design [4], and material
discovery [5], among many more. However, we seldom see the machine learning community benchmark new methods in physical science datasets, mostly due to the difficulty in cleaning real-world
data, the need for interdisciplinary understanding to correctly benchmark, and most importantly, how
expensive the data can be to produce, resulting in many datasets being locked behind closed doors by
large companies.
AIchemy (https://aichemy.ac.uk) is an interdisciplinary UK hub with the mission of transforming the chemistry-AI interface via aiding the collaboration of chemists and AI researchers, as well as
addressing gaps in data standards, curation, and availability for AI use. In partnership with SOLVE
Chemistry (https://www.solvechemistry.com), we present a first important step into addressing
the dataset gap with the introduction of a new and unique open dataset for benchmarking low-data
machine learning algorithms for chemistry.
Solvent selection is one of the biggest challenges for chemical manufacturing, with solvents often
being the main source of waste in the manufacturing process [6]. Increased regulation on solvents and
a drive to making process manufacturing more sustainable led to an interest in the discovery of greener

Figure 1: Data was gathered on the rearrangement of allyl substituted catechol. By subjecting the

solvents and for improved solvent replacement tools. However, most of the solvent replacement tools
focus purely on learning unsupervised representations of solvents, with the hope that experimentalists
can find solvents with similar properties to replace those with environmental concerns. A much
stronger approach would consider the interaction of a variety of different solvents with a reaction of
interest to directly predict reaction yields, in such a way that the best possible solvent can be selected
according to a yield-sustainability trade-off.
Machine learning approaches have been shown to be a powerful tool for the prediction of chemical
reaction conditions. Success has been reported in retro-synthesis [7, 8], condition recommendations
[9], product predictions [10, 11], among others. While yield prediction has proven to be more difficult
due to large inconsistencies in procedure and data reporting [12], we have still seen promising yield
prediction results for smaller and more carefully curated datasets [13–16]. However, these datasets
lack the continuous reaction conditions, such as temperature and residence time, that are required to
scale-up processes to practical manufacturing conditions.
In this paper, we release the first machine-learning-ready transient flow dataset, a framework that
allows for quick and efficient screening of continuous reaction conditions. We specifically provide
yield data over the uni-molecular allyl substituted catechol reaction, shown in Figure 1, with dense
measurements across the residence time, temperature, and solvent space. We answer the call for
more flow chemistry reaction data [17], further showcase how this type of kinetic data poses new
challenges to current machine learning methods for chemistry, and identify potential solutions.
1.1 Related works
Reaction datasets are common in chemistry research, but their suitability for machine learning
benchmarking tends to be poor. This can be a result of improper formatting or documentation,
incomplete information about reaction conditions or the experimental set-up, or the lack of machine
readability, leading to limited usage by the ML community. However, some effort has been made
to address this, with the biggest example being the creation of the Open Reaction Database (ORD)
[18], a repository containing over 2M different reactions, many of which come from US patent data
(USPTO) [19]. However, the dataset falls short in some aspects, in particular with respect to machine
learning readiness and data inconsistencies across reactions.
ORDerly [12] allows for easy cleaning and preparation of ORD data, showing the promise of the
dataset for forward and retro-synthetic prediction using transformers; however, it also shows that
yield prediction cannot be done well due to data inconsistencies. Schwaller et al. [13] drew similar
conclusions when using the USPTO dataset, stating that reaction conditions such as temperature,
concentrations, and duration have a significant effect on yield. The assumption that every reaction in
the dataset is optimized for reaction parameters proved too loose, resulting in inaccurate predictive
models for yield, and highlighting the importance of creating datasets with full (including potentially
sub-optimal) reaction conditions.
More relevant to our work, Perera et al. [20] introduced a dataset of 5760 Suzuki-Miyaura crosscoupling reactions, Ahneman et al. [21] introduced a dataset of 3956 Buchwald–Hartwig aminations,
and Prieto Kullmer et al. [22] investigated screening additives for Ni-catalysed reactions, all for the
purposes of yield prediction. The datasets have been used in the benchmarking of Gaussian processes
and Bayesian neural networks [14], deep learning models [13], language-model-based embeddings
2
[16], data augmentation techniques [23], and Bayesian optimisation [15]. In each case, the datasets
focus on discrete reaction variables, such as ligand, base, additives, or reactants at fixed temperatures
and residence times. We are instead introducing a dataset rich in continuous reaction conditions (in
our case temperature and residence time), as well as providing a pseudo-continuous representation of
solvents themselves through the use of solvent mixtures.
